triples.evidence: In MATLAB, we can perform circular convolution using the Fourier transform approach.
The red dashed curve is the linear convolution result from our earlier example.

concepts.term: The blue curve is the circular convolution result without zero-padding.

evidence: The legend in the plot labels the red dashed curve as 'Linear Conv', which represents lconv.
Here’s where we can clearly see the difference between linear convolution and circular convolution without zero padding.
In MATLAB, we can perform circular convolution using the Fourier transform approach.
Multiplication in the frequency domain is equivalent to convolution in the time domain - but here’s the key point: if we don’t use zero-padding, the convolution we get is circular by nature.
Notice how the blue curve is the circular convolution result without zero-padding. The red dashed curve is the linear convolution result from our earlier example.
This is why zero-padding is essential when we want the frequency-domain method to give the same result as linear convolution. Without it, circular convolution will give you something different.
